## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 79, 615, 97]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 139, 576, 159]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 171, 255, 191]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 201, 400, 221]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 220, 596, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 278, 243, 295]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 297, 767, 339]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 351, 514, 390]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 415, 400, 435]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 440, 549, 470]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 351, 513]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 515, 445, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 617, 610, 636]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 650, 171, 667]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 678, 598, 730]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \sec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 772, 256, 790]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 798, 608, 835]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 833, 610, 853]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 860, 571, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of the constant \(k\) such that the equation \(kx^{2} + 4kx + 3k + 1 = 0\) has two different real roots. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 851, 100]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\cos \mathrm{e} \mathrm{c}^{2} \theta + 2 \cot^{2} \theta = 2 \cot \theta + 9\), where \(\theta\) is in radians and \(- \frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 76, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 94, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 84, 144, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the first three non-zero terms in the expansion of \(\left(2 - \frac{x^2}{4}\right)^6\) in ascending powers of \(x\). Simplify each term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 144, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 490, 761, 524]]<|/det|>
Hence find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(2 - \frac{x^2}{4}\right)^6 \left(3 - \frac{1}{x^2}\right)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
When \(\mathrm{e}^{y}\) is plotted against \(x^{2}\) a straight line graph passing through the points (2.24, 5) and (4.74, 10) is obtained. Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 84, 640, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle, centre \(O\), radius \(2a\). The points \(A\) and \(B\) lie on the circumference of the circle. The points \(C\) and \(D\) are the mid-points of the lines \(OB\) and \(OA\) respectively. The arc \(DC\) is part of a circle centre \(O\). The chord \(AB\) is of length \(2a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 361, 144, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 635, 380]]<|/det|>
Find angle \(AOB\), giving your answer in radians in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 146, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 688, 549]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\) and \(\pi\), the perimeter of the shaded region \(ABCD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 701, 144, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 645, 720]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\) and \(\pi\), the area of the shaded region \(ABCD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A committee of 8 people is to be formed from 5 teachers, 4 doctors and 3 police officers. Find the number of different committees that could be chosen if

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 467, 135]]<|/det|>
all 4 doctors are on the committee,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 180, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 319, 551, 337]]<|/det|>
there are at least 2 teachers on the committee.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 146, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 534, 570]]<|/det|>
Given that \(^{n}\mathrm{P}_{5} = 6 \times^{n - 1} \mathrm{P}_{4}\), find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 92, 902, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 915, 395]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the curve \(y = a\cos bx + c\), for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant 2.8\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are constants and \(x\) is

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 861, 428]]<|/det|>
in radians. The curve meets the \(y\)-axis at (0, 3) and the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P\) and point \(R\big(\frac{5\pi}{6}, 0\big)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 720, 456]]<|/det|>
The curve has a minimum at point \(Q\). The period of \(a\cos bx + c\) is \(\pi\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 143, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 438, 485]]<|/det|>
Find the value of each of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 466, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 669, 146, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 361, 687]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 668, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 777, 144, 796]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 777, 363, 796]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 777, 920, 796]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 99, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation of the curve \(y = \big(x^{2} - 4\big)\big(x - 2\big)\) can be written as \(y = x^{3} + ax^{2} + bx + 8\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers. Hence find the exact coordinates of the stationary points on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 146, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 399, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \left|(x^{2} - 4)(x - 2)\right|\), stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 420, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 453, 873, 752]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 771, 144, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 766, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of the constant \(k\) for which \(\left|(x^{2} - 4)(x - 2)\right| = k\) has exactly 4 different solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 787, 920, 806]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 88, 811, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the parallelogram \(OABC\), such that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OC} = \mathbf{c}\). The point \(D\) lies on \(CB\) such that \(CD:DB = 3:1\). When extended, the lines \(AB\) and \(OD\) meet at the point \(E\). It is given that \(\overrightarrow{OE} = h\overrightarrow{OD}\) and \(\overrightarrow{BE} = k\overrightarrow{AB}\), where \(h\) and \(k\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 369, 144, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 369, 405, 388]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{DE}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\), \(\mathbf{c}\) and \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 371, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 403, 94]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{DE}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{c}\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 76, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 201, 144, 219]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 201, 428, 219]]<|/det|>
Hence find the value of \(h\) and of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 201, 920, 219]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The line \(x + 2y = 10\) intersects the two lines satisfying the equation \(\left|x + y\right| = 2\) at the points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 144, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 120, 774, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that the point \(C(- 5, 20)\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of the line \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) also lies on this perpendicular bisector. \(M\) is the mid-point of \(AB\). The distance \(CD\) is three times the distance of \(CM\). Find the possible coordinates of \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
